description: This course takes a deep dive into mail merge within Word 2016 for Mac.  Mail merge is a powerful function to batch process personalized letters or emails as well as create mailing labels and envelopes. The hosts take extra time to explain the different types of data sources that can be used, how to create letters and emails, how to add images to envelopes and labels, and apply rules to extend the capabilities of the mail merge process.  This is course is specifically for Word 2016 fon the Macintosh operating system (Mac OS).

00:16:21.138 --> 00:16:23.197
like the actual results of everything.

321
00:16:23.197 --> 00:16:24.983
I don't want to send somebody 19 files.

322
00:16:24.983 --> 00:16:29.399
Now that I have 19, we're talking about,
what if there's 19,000, or 1,900?

323
00:16:29.399 --> 00:16:33.693
That's where you don't want
to have individual files,

324
00:16:33.693 --> 00:16:37.009
it's all one file, and it creates a break.

325
00:16:37.009 --> 00:16:40.923
Actually, here, I have it down here,
let's come back down over to my computer,

326
00:16:40.923 --> 00:16:41.789
see right there?

327
00:16:41.789 --> 00:16:44.643
It creates a next page section break.

328
00:16:44.643 --> 00:16:47.517
So it found the one, and then it
goes right onto the next record, and

329
00:16:47.517 --> 00:16:50.003
then break, next record, and
then break, next record.

330
00:16:50.003 --> 00:16:53.145
Because you might have
your start document, or

331
00:16:53.145 --> 00:16:55.746
the one that you've had as your merge.

332
00:16:55.746 --> 00:16:59.402
And by the way, I'm using command
tilde to switch between open

333
00:16:59.402 --> 00:17:01.820
documents within the Word application.

334
00:17:01.820 --> 00:17:06.014
In your merge, this is one page, but
you could have two pages in there.

335
00:17:06.014 --> 00:17:10.357
You could have to where you have
a letter that is two pages.

336
00:17:10.357 --> 00:17:10.886
>> Right.

337
00:17:10.886 --> 00:17:12.438
>> And you have your 19 recipients,

338
00:17:12.438 --> 00:17:15.747
well, then it's going to do your two
pages, break, then the next record,

339
00:17:15.747 --> 00:17:16.743
then the next record.

340
00:17:16.743 --> 00:17:20.757
So it doesn't have to be just
a single page to start and

341
00:17:20.757 --> 00:17:24.878
have your merge,
it can be as many pages as it needs to.

342
00:17:24.878 --> 00:17:27.327
And you can have merged
fields all over the place.

343
00:17:27.327 --> 00:17:29.775
We're trying to make it a little
bit simpler of an example.

344
00:17:29.775 --> 00:17:30.386
>> Right.

345
00:17:30.386 --> 00:17:32.727
>> But that's the idea of the finished

346
00:17:32.727 --> 00:17:38.361
file, having those sections adds to every
change in your record of your data source.

347
00:17:38.361 --> 00:17:40.934
And it goes ahead and
gives you this as your result.

348
00:17:40.934 --> 00:17:41.746
>> Pretty cool.

349
00:17:41.746 --> 00:17:44.590
>> Pretty cool, yeah, really, really neat.

350
00:17:44.590 --> 00:17:47.866
But back on that merged
file back over here, that,

351
00:17:47.866 --> 00:17:51.608
the command that everyone always
gets lost on is this one.

352
00:17:51.608 --> 00:17:53.928
Where you have to take
your merged document,

353
00:17:53.928 --> 00:17:57.483
where you have all of your fields and
you've composed your letters.

354
00:17:57.483 --> 00:18:00.096
And you need to edit
the individual document.

355
00:18:00.096 --> 00:18:02.610
That's what's going to go ahead and

356
00:18:02.610 --> 00:18:06.840
create that separate file with
the different pages in there.

357
00:18:06.840 --> 00:18:09.612
Now, you could, if you wanted to,
go straight to printing.

358
00:18:09.612 --> 00:18:12.913
But that's like, okay, I've connected
to printer, it's just going to go.

359
00:18:12.913 --> 00:18:16.732
But I don't,
you don't have to have a finished file,

360
00:18:16.732 --> 00:18:19.556
but I think it's the best way to go.
>> So,

361
00:18:19.556 --> 00:18:24.741
I just to make sure I'm totally
understanding this, once I edit that file,

362
00:18:24.741 --> 00:18:27.100
will it be a separate file?
>> Yes.

363
00:18:27.100 --> 00:18:28.591
>> So, like, hey, I want to go ahead and

Maybe they have a private showing of
my new art exhibit, or whatever, and

00:18:34.110 --> 00:18:38.183

370
00:18:48.700 --> 00:18:49.593

371
00:18:49.593 --> 00:18:53.146
But you could come back over
to your finished document and

372
00:18:53.146 --> 00:18:54.637

373
00:18:54.637 --> 00:18:59.624
Or maybe pumpkin squash, just this one,

00:18:59.624 --> 00:19:01.447

375
00:19:01.447 --> 00:19:02.383

376
00:19:02.383 --> 00:19:04.353
>> What if you wanted to keep it in line,

00:19:04.353 --> 00:19:06.189

378
00:19:06.189 --> 00:19:07.698
>> As one big document, or

00:19:07.698 --> 00:19:11.937

380
00:19:11.937 --> 00:19:14.771
When you do the edit and
edit individual results,

00:19:14.771 --> 00:19:17.244
it will always produce a separate file.

382
00:19:17.244 --> 00:19:19.465
You're saying, the merge and

383
00:19:19.465 --> 00:19:21.142
>> Yeah, so, just to make sure,

384
00:19:21.142 --> 00:19:25.593
because if I'm thinking, hey, I only have
a few changes, it's probably best to

385
00:19:25.593 --> 00:19:28.479

>> It depends.

386
00:19:28.479 --> 00:19:30.276
>> Plan for having two separate or

387
00:19:30.276 --> 00:19:32.072
multiple files.
>> Exactly, and

388
00:19:32.072 --> 00:19:36.340
that's actually a really good point,
of like, where do I want to do my editing?

389
00:19:36.340 --> 00:19:40.599
Do I want to go back and edit the source
data, like the actual Excel file and

390
00:19:40.599 --> 00:19:42.815
make sure I change everything there?

391
00:19:42.815 --> 00:19:48.477
Because this document is gonna,
the merge one, if I update my data source.

392
00:19:48.477 --> 00:19:51.312
If I add more records, it's just
going to keep pulling from there.

393
00:19:51.312 --> 00:19:51.839
>> Okay.

394
00:19:51.839 --> 00:19:52.730
>> It just, it's like, hey,

395
00:19:52.730 --> 00:19:54.003
whatever's in there, it's going to.

396
00:19:54.003 --> 00:19:58.874
So you can edit your data source,
and then take the merge document,

397
00:19:58.874 --> 00:20:01.956
go ahead and produce your final document.

398
00:20:01.956 --> 00:20:06.202
And everything will just come over
because of the data source connection.

399
00:20:06.202 --> 00:20:08.795
Or you can then take the finished file and

400
00:20:08.795 --> 00:20:11.704
then do any type of
individual editing here.

401
00:20:11.704 --> 00:20:15.901
So it really just depends on which
place you want to go ahead and

402
00:20:15.901 --> 00:20:19.224
make your adjustments.
>> Okay, and then also, I'm just trying to

403
00:20:19.224 --> 00:20:21.092
wrap my head around all of this.
>> Yeah, no.

404
00:20:21.092 --> 00:20:21.743
>> Okay.

405
00:20:21.743 --> 00:20:22.796
>> Definitely, keep going, [LAUGH].

406
00:20:22.796 --> 00:20:25.071
>> So the original source file,

00:20:25.071 --> 00:20:30.720
if you change the location to that,

00:20:30.720 --> 00:20:33.016
Do you need to keep it in the same place,

409
00:20:33.016 --> 00:20:34.646
>> That is fantastic.

410
00:20:34.646 --> 00:20:35.540
>> [LAUGH]

411
00:20:35.540 --> 00:20:37.302
>> Yes, because it's still gonna,

00:20:37.302 --> 00:20:38.847
it's like a path.
>> Yeah.

413
00:20:38.847 --> 00:20:40.776
>> So, when you have your Word document

00:20:40.776 --> 00:20:44.658
that has a conection to that Excel file,

00:20:44.658 --> 00:20:48.806
And you move that Excel file, it's still
going to look at that place and be like,

00:20:48.806 --> 00:20:50.321
I don't see it.

00:20:50.321 --> 00:20:51.621

00:20:51.621 --> 00:20:53.909

00:20:53.909 --> 00:20:54.682

420
00:20:54.682 --> 00:20:55.293
>> [LAUGH]

00:20:56.389 --> 00:20:56.915
>> Okay.

423
00:20:56.915 --> 00:20:57.685
>> Like say, hey,

00:20:59.948 --> 00:21:04.847
And then, okay, now I understand it's

00:21:04.847 --> 00:21:07.880

427
00:21:07.880 --> 00:21:10.435

For some reason, you deleted this whole

you have last-

00:21:20.781 --> 00:21:22.131
>> Yeah, so if you mess that up,

00:21:22.131 --> 00:21:25.592

00:21:25.592 --> 00:21:27.731
It's going to be like,
I don't have a last field anymore.

434
00:21:27.731 --> 00:21:28.419
>> Okay.

435
00:21:28.419 --> 00:21:29.682

00:21:29.682 --> 00:21:31.932

00:21:31.932 --> 00:21:33.575

>> Yes,

00:21:33.575 --> 00:21:34.202

00:21:41.149 --> 00:21:46.504

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Cherokee take a closer look at data sources, specifically covering the option for using existing lists.  They explain and show different files that can be used for a mailing list (data source) such as .xlsx, .csv, .txt,  and even .docx with a table.  They also explain the Excel Workbook text converter warning when using Excel files as the data source as well as tips for formatting data in Excel to ensure the best result in the merge.
episodes.title: Data Sources: Existing List

episodes.description: Things don't always work perfectly. In this episode, Vonne and Daniel troubleshoot issues associated with using Excel files as a data source. They discuss issues with opening existing files that are connected to an Excel file, different error messages, and other issues with the Excel Workbook text converter. They also troubleshoot missing field warnings when previewing results.
episodes.title: Data Sources: Existing List Part 2

episodes.description: Daniel and Vonne continue to discuss and troubleshoot issues that might occur with existing lists. In this episode, they cover issues with .csv and tab delimited files, specifically problems with encoding and extra or missing delimiters. They also show issues with using a Word table with extra information and how it previews in the mail merge results.

episodes.description: Vonne and Cherokee focus on using either Outlook or Apple contacts as a data source for mail merge. They explain the importance of designating your default Email application and how it relates to your options  for a data source in a mail merge in Word.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Vonne demonstrate how to create an impromptu mailing list as a data source. They show how to remove premade fields and add custom fields in the Edit Fields dialog box and then adding records into the table in the created Word file data source.

episodes.description: Cherokee and Vonne dive into composing a letter with merged fields. They review and combine the information presented in the introduction and data source episodes, show how to insert fields, preview results, and merge and finish for a final document. They also demonstrate how to change a data source in a merged document and review and troubleshoot issues with missing data source files.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Vonne demonstrate how to add images to labels to both mail merge labels and full page of same labels. Vonne gives lots of tips and tricks, from personal experience, to align images in labels without having to pull your hair out in frustration.

episodes.description: Cherokee and Vonne explore how to create envelopes both individually and with a mail merge. They cover filling out the return and delivery address in the envelopes dialog box, format addresses, and the overall layout of the resulting envelope.  They also show how to insert an envelope into the current document and review some tips for creating envelopes to conform to post office standards.
episodes.title: Envelopes

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Cherokee show how to use mail merge to send bulk email messages. They discuss the importance of setting Outlook as the default email application for your Mac and having the recipient's email address in the data source. They also review the different ways to send the merged email - plain text, HTML, or as attachment

episodes.description: Being able to control what records to use in a mail merge is important. In this episode, Vonne and Cherokee show how to use filter and sort on merged records. They also show how to find a specific record in a mail merge.
episodes.title: Filter, Sort, Find

episodes.description: Cherokee and Vonne continue to demonstrate rules for mail merge.  In this episode, they specifically cover the if then else rule and how it can be used to write conditional statements to further extend the personalization of mail merge messages.
